text.p: Raytheon Co said Friday it was considering more acquisitions to achieve the critical mass necessary to compete effectively in the defense business.

Raytheon Chief Executive Dennis Picard has told analysts that "the option we're considering is not getting out of the defense business...but that there is the potential for acquisitions to reach critical mass," Raytheon spokeswoman Elizabeth Allen told Reuters.
According to published reports earlier this week, Texas Instruments is planning to sell its defense electronics holdings worth more than $2 billion.
Parties interested in the business include Raytheon, McDonnell Douglas Corp, Northrop Grumman Corp and Hughes Electronics Corp, according to reports.
Allen declined to comment on whether Raytheon had any interest in acquiring the Texas Instruments defense electronics business.
Despite Raytheon's $2.3 billion acquisition of E-Systems in 1995, mergers among competitors in the defense industry have caused Raytheon to examine whether it had achieved critical mass, Allen said.
"You are looking at three very, very large competitors," she said. "I think everybody agrees you have to have critical mass to compete."
"Our strategy has been to grow both our defense and our commercial side through acquisitions. We have the capacity to keep doing that," she said.
